hints.content: Start by identifying the cells that belong to the letter Y. Remember that the Y consists of two diagonals and a vertical line. For an n x n grid, the center cell is located at (n // 2, n // 2).
Once you have identified the Y cells, count the number of cells in the Y shape. This will help you understand how many cells need to be uniform in value.
Next, consider the values of the cells that belong to the Y. You need to determine which value (0, 1, or 2) would require the least number of changes to make all Y cells the same.
For each possible value (0, 1, 2) for the Y cells, calculate how many operations are needed to convert all Y cells to that value. Keep track of the minimum operations required.
Now, focus on the cells that do not belong to the Y. You need to ensure that all these cells have the same value, which must be different from the value chosen for the Y cells.
Count the occurrences of each value (0, 1, 2) in the non-Y cells. This will help you determine how many operations are needed to convert them all to a single value.
Remember that the value chosen for the non-Y cells must differ from the value chosen for the Y cells. This means you might need to consider combinations of values for both sets.
Try to calculate the total number of operations required for different combinations of values for Y and non-Y cells. Keep track of the minimum total operations across all combinations.
Be mindful of edge cases, such as when the grid is filled with the same value already. In such cases, you may need to make adjustments to ensure the uniqueness of values for Y and non-Y.
Finally, implement your logic to return the minimum number of operations needed. Ensure that you are correctly handling the grid indexing and the constraints provided.

questionNotes: n is odd, which means there is a clear center cell at (n // 2, n // 2).
The values in the grid can only be 0, 1, or 2.
All Y cells must be the same value, and all non-Y cells must also be the same but different from Y cells.
Return the minimum number of operations needed to achieve the desired configuration.
